Paradise is open year-round, but this orientation guide is designed for the summer season when trails are snow-free. In spring and fall, there may be patches of snow covering sections of trail. Please stay on trails, even if it means crossing snow, to avoid trampling delicate meadow plants. Pets are not allowed on trails.

This location is the junction of Deadhorse Creek Trail and Glacier Moraine Trail, with north looking towards Gibraltar Rock on the eastern slopes of Mount Rainier (the summit is slightly more northwest).

  • Deadhorse Creek Trail goes to the east uphill and to the southwest downhill.
  • Moraine Trail starts at this junction and heads to the west before turning northwest. After the first half-mile this trail is unmaintained and can be hazardous.

How Far Is It?

  • Lower Parking Lot: 0.74 miles, average walking time 29 minutes, southwest on Deadhorse Creek Trail (downhill). The trail connects to the Nisqually Vista Trailhead shortly before connecting to the lower parking lot. There are no restrooms in the lower parking lot, but restrooms are available in the Paradise Picnic Area, downhill from the parking lot.
  • Connecting to upper Skyline Trail: 0.47 miles, average walking time 18 minutes, east on Deadhorse Creek Trail (uphill).
  • Jackson Visitor Center and Upper Parking Lot: 0.69 miles, average walking time 27 minutes, by following the Deadhorse Creek Trail downhill to the Waterfall Trail to connect to the upper parking lot. Restrooms, information, food, and gifts available at the visitor center.

For additional information, download the Paradise Area Trails Map.
audioDescription: At this three-way intersection the narrow, dirt Moraine Trail departs from the wider, paved Deadhorse Creek Trail. The edges of the paved trail may be abrupt or bordered by rocks, while the dirt trail is uneven. Both trails are bordered by subalpine meadows dotted with boulders with excellent views of the glaciated summit of Mount Rainier and the Tatoosh Range. A small sign next to the start of the Moraine Trail reads “Moraine Trail – End of Trail .5”

title: Paradise Trails Orientation: Deadhorse Creek & Skyline Connector Trail Junction
listingDescription: This location is the junction of Deadhorse Creek Trail and a Skyline connector trail.

images.altText: A paved trail connects to another paved trail on the meadow slope of a glaciated mountain.
images.title: Deadhorse Creek and Skyline Connector
images.caption: The Deadhorse Creek Trail climbs the slopes of Mount Rainier, with the summit to the northwest.

bodyText:
Season: Summer
Paradise is open year-round, but this orientation guide is designed for the summer season when trails are snow-free. In spring and fall, there may be patches of snow covering sections of trail. Please stay on trails, even if it means crossing snow, to avoid trampling delicate meadow plants. Pets are not allowed on trails.

This location is the junction of Deadhorse Creek Trail and a connector trail to the Skyline Trail. The Deadhorse Creek Trail goes uphill to the north, with Mount Rainier’s summit to the northwest.

  • Deadhorse Creek Trail goes to the north uphill and to the south downhill.
  • The connector trail goes downhill to the southeast to connect to the Skyline Trail.  

How Far Is It?

  • Lower Parking Lot: 0.80 miles, average walking time 31 minutes, south on Deadhorse Creek Trail (downhill). The trail connects to the Nisqually Vista Trailhead shortly before connecting to the lower parking lot. There are no restrooms in the lower parking lot, but restrooms are available in the Paradise Picnic Area, downhill from the parking lot.
  • Connecting to Skyline Trail: 0.09 miles, average walking time 4 minutes, southeast on the connector trail (downhill). Or, continue to follow the Deadhorse Creek Trail uphill to connect to the Skyline Trail when the Deadhorse Trail terminates, 0.41 miles, average walking time 16 minutes.
  • Jackson Visitor Center and Upper Parking Lot: 0.56 miles, average walking time 22 minutes, by following the connector trail downhill to the Skyline Trail to descend to the upper parking lot. Restrooms, information, food, and gifts available at the visitor center.

For additional information, download the Paradise Area Trails Map.
audioDescription: At this three-way intersection the paved Deadhorse Creek Trail travels up and down the slopes of Mount Rainier while the short, paved connector trail diagonally cuts downhill across a slope to reach the Skyline Trail to the east. The edges of the paved trails may be abrupt or bordered by rocks. Both trails are bordered by subalpine meadows dotted with boulders with excellent views of the glaciated summit of Mount Rainier and the Tatoosh Range. Between the downhill branch of the Deadhorse Creek Trail and the connector trail a log serves as a low bench. A short trail sign is set into the ground in front of the bench, with another trail sign next to the Deadhorse Creek Trail across from the connector trail.

title: Paradise Trails Orientation: Deadhorse Creek & Waterfall Trail Junction
listingDescription: This location is the junction of Deadhorse Creek Trail and Waterfall Trail

images.altText: A glaciated mountain rises above autumn meadows and a paved trail intersection.
images.title: Deadhorse creek-waterfall trail junction
images.caption: Looking north from the Waterfall Trail towards Mount Rainier.

bodyText:
Season: Summer
Paradise is open year-round, but this orientation guide is designed for the summer season when trails are snow-free. In spring and fall, there may be patches of snow covering sections of trail. Please stay on trails, even if it means crossing snow, to avoid trampling delicate meadow plants. Pets are not allowed on trails.

This location is the junction of Deadhorse Creek Trail and Waterfall Trail, with north located midway between the two branches of Deadhorse Creek Trail (opposite the Waterfall Trail) looking roughly towards Mount Rainier.

  • Deadhorse Creek Trail goes to the northeast uphill and to the northwest downhill before curving to the south.
  • Waterfall Trail starts at this junction and travels to the southeast with views of the Tatoosh Range.

How Far Is It?

  • Lower Parking Lot: 0.42 miles, average walking time 16 minutes, south on Deadhorse Creek Trail (downhill). The trail connects to the Nisqually Vista Trailhead shortly before connecting to the lower parking lot. There are no restrooms in the lower parking lot, but restrooms are available in the Paradise Picnic Area, downhill from the parking lot.
  • Connecting to upper Skyline Trail: 0.79 miles, average walking time 30 minutes, northeast on Deadhorse Creek Trail (uphill).
  • Jackson Visitor Center and Upper Parking Lot: 0.37 miles, average walking time 15 minutes, by following the Waterfall Trail southeast to the Skyline Trail then taking the Skyline Trail downhill to the upper parking lot. Restrooms, information, food, and gifts available at the visitor center.

For additional information, download the Paradise Area Trails Map.
audioDescription: At this three-way intersection the Waterfall Trail connects to the Deadhorse Creek Trail. The Waterfall Trail traverses across the slope while the Deadhorse Creek Trail follows the path of the creek, climbing up through subalpine meadows dotted with fir trees. The downhill portion of the trail crosses over the creek then curves to follow the edge of the creek downhill. Both trails are paved. Edges may be abrupt and uneven or bordered by rocks.

title: Paradise Trails Orientation: East Skyline & 4th Crossing Trail Junction
listingDescription: This location is the junction of the East Skyline Trail and 4th Crossing Trail.

images.altText: Wooden bridge surrounded by conifer trees with glaciated mountain in background
images.title: East Skyline Trail & 4th Crossing
images.caption: Looking northwest along the East Skyline Trail towards Mount Rainier

bodyText:
Season: Summer 

Paradise is open year-round, but this orientation guide is designed for the summer season when trails are snow-free. In spring and fall, there may be patches of snow covering sections of trail. Please stay on trails, even if it means crossing snow, to avoid trampling delicate meadow plants. Pets are not allowed on trails.  

This location is the junction of East Skyline Trail and 4th Crossing Trail. The summit of Mount Rainier is located northwest of this intersection. 

  • East Skyline Trail is oriented roughly east-west at this intersection, with the downhill trail to west when facing Mount Rainier (northwest) and the uphill trail to southeast. 
  • 4th Crossing Trail goes downhill to the southwest, connecting to the Paradise Valley Road.  

How Far Is It?  

  • Paradise Valley Road: 0.3 miles, average walking time 12 minutes, heading southeast on the 4th Crossing Trail. 
  • Connecting to Lower Golden Gate Trail: 0.5 miles, average walking time 19 minutes, heading northwest and then west on the Skyline Trail. 
  • Paradise (Jackson Visitor Center and Upper Parking Lot): 0.7 miles, average walking time 27 minutes, following Skyline Trail downhill to the west and then to the southwest.
  • Connecting to Paradise Glacier Trail: 1.0 mile, average walking time 39 minutes, following East Skyline Trail uphill to the southeast and then to the northeast. 
  • Connecting to Mazama Ridge / Lakes Trail: 0.4 miles, average walking time 15 minutes, following East Skyline Trail uphill to the southeast. The Mazama Ridge / Lakes Trail continues to the south.  

For additional information, download the Paradise Area Trails Map.
audioDescription: This T-shaped trail junction is surrounded by conifer trees and open patches of meadows. The trail is dirt with wooden steps. There is a wooden bridge to the northwest of this location.

title: Paradise Trails Orientation: East Skyline & Guide House Connector Trail Junction
listingDescription: This location is the junction of East Skyline Trail and the Guide House Connector Trail.

images.altText: An exhibit panel on a rock wall south of an intersection of two paved trails.
images.title: Skyline-Guide House Trail Junction
images.caption: Looking north from the Guide House Connector Trail.

bodyText:
Season: Summer
Paradise is open year-round, but this orientation guide is designed for the summer season when trails are snow-free. In spring and fall, there may be patches of snow covering sections of trail. Please stay on trails, even if it means crossing snow, to avoid trampling delicate meadow plants. Pets are not allowed on trails.

At this trail intersection, the Guide House Connector Trail crosses the East Skyline Trail to reach the Guide House, home to the Paradise Wilderness (Climbing) Information Center, and terminates at the upper parking lot near the Paradise Inn. The “Paradise Extreme Snow Exhibit Panel”, which overlooks the Paradise Inn, is located near the trail intersection.

  • East Skyline Trail is relatively flat at this location, with an easy climb to the northeast and a gentle downhill slope to the southwest.
  • Guide House Connector Trail goes due north towards Mount Rainier and the junction with the Skyline and Alta Vista Trails. To the south the trail connects to the Guide House and upper parking lot, with the Paradise Inn to the east.

How Far Is It?

  • Guide House and Paradise Wilderness (Climbing) Information Center: 0.03 miles, average walking time one minute, by following the Guide House Connector Trail downhill to the south, then bear to the right (west) to take the path to the Guide House Entrance. The Paradise Wilderness Information Center is open during the summer and provides maps, information, and climbing permits.
  • Paradise Inn: 0.03 miles, average walking time one minute, by following Guide House Connector Trail downhill to the south, then bear to the left (east) to reach the upper parking lot and Paradise Inn. The Paradise Inn has a restaurant, café, gift shop, and a comfortable lobby for those looking to take a break. The Paradise Inn is located on the eastern edge of the upper parking lot.
  • Jackson Visitor Center and Upper Parking Lot: 0.09 miles, average walking time 4 minutes, by following East Skyline Trail to the southwest. Restrooms, water, and gift shop are located in the visitor center. You can also follow the Guide House Connector Trail south to the upper parking lot and walk to the western edge of the parking lot to reach the visitor center.
  • Myrtle Falls: 0.43 miles, average walking time 17 minutes, by following East Skyline Trail to the northeast.
  • Connecting to Alta Vista Trail: 0.16 miles, average walking time 7 minutes, by following the Guide House Connector Trail to the north to the junction of the Skyline and Alta Vista Trail.

For additional information, download the Paradise Area Trails Map.
audioDescription: The East Skyline Trail is a wide paved trail that gently cuts across the meadow slopes in this location. The meadows are broken by numerous patches of fir trees, with Mount Rainier’s snowy peak just visible between the trees to the north. The Guide House Connector Trail is also paved, but narrower, and climbs steeply to the north. To the south, the connector trail widens and wraps around an exhibit panel installed on a low rock stand in the middle of the trail. The exhibit panel is oriented so that it overlooks the Paradise Inn to the east. A trail branches off to the right to connect to the guide house while another trail past the exhibit panel descends into the upper parking lot in front of the Paradise Inn. The edges of the paved trails can be abrupt and bordered by low ropes strung between rebar posts to help remind people to stay on the trail.

title: Paradise Trails Orientation: East Skyline & Lower Goldengate Trail Junction
listingDescription: This location is the junction of East Skyline Trail and the lower Goldengate Trail.

images.altText: A trail with log steps climbs up through a meadow towards a glaciated peak.
images.title: Goldengate-East Skyline Trail
images.caption: The Goldengate Trail climbs north towards Mount Rainier off of the Skyline Trail.

bodyText:
Season: Summer
Paradise is open year-round, but this orientation guide is designed for the summer season when trails are snow-free. In spring and fall, there may be patches of snow covering sections of trail. Please stay on trails, even if it means crossing snow, to avoid trampling delicate meadow plants. Pets are not allowed on trails.

This location is the lower junction of East Skyline Trail and the Goldengate Trail. The Goldengate Trail climbs steeply to connect to the East Skyline Trail at the upper junction, creating a shortcut for those who don’t want to hike the full Skyline loop trail. The Goldengate Trail cuts a mile off of the total trail length. The Goldengate Trail switchbacks through a section of subalpine meadow with excellent views of Mount Rainier to the north, Tatoosh Range to the south, and Alta Vista to the west. Please stay on trail to protect the wildflowers.

  • East Skyline Trail goes uphill to the northeast and downhill to the south, where it crosses over Edith Creek just above Myrtle Falls.
  • Goldengate Trail climbs steeply to the north towards Mount Rainier.

How Far Is It?

  • Paradise Inn: 0.40 miles, average walking time 16 minutes, by following East Skyline Trail downhill to the south. The Paradise Inn will be visible on the left. It has a restaurant, café, gift shop, and a comfortable lobby for those looking to take a break.
  • Jackson Visitor Center and Upper Parking Lot: 0.46 miles, average walking time 18 minutes, by following East Skyline Trail downhill to the south. Restrooms, water, and gift shop are located in the visitor center.
  • Connecting to upper East Skyline Trail: 1 mile, average walking time 39 minutes, north on the Goldengate Trail. This route is steep, climbing 800 feet through a subalpine meadow. Or, stay on the Skyline Trail to take the longer route, 2 miles, average walking time 1 hour, 17 minutes. The full Skyline Trail loop is 5.5 miles long.
  • Connecting to 4th Crossing & Paradise Valley Road: 0.8 miles, average walking time 31 minutes, heading northeast on the East Skyline Trail. The 4th Crossing Trail then drops down to the south to connect to the Paradise Valley Road.

For additional information, download the Paradise Area Trails Map.
audioDescription: The Goldengate Trail branches off of the East Skyline Trail, which continues to curve around the top of the Paradise Valley, a small valley with patches of fir trees and subalpine meadow. Both trails are dirt, broken by rocks and log steps. The Goldengate Trail climbs up through a large subalpine meadow. The edges of the trail can be bordered by rope strung between rebar posts to help remind people to stay on the trail. Both trails have excellent views of the surrounding subalpine meadows, ridges, the glaciated peak of Mount Rainier and surrounding mountains.

title: Paradise Trails Orientation: East Skyline & Mazama Ridge Trail Junction
listingDescription: This location is the junction of the East Skyline Trail and Mazama Ridge Trail.

images.altText: T-shaped trail intersection surrounded by open patches of meadow and conifer trees
images.title: East Skyline Trail & Mazama Ridge Trail
images.caption: Looking east on the East Skyline Trail at the junction of Mazama Ridge / Lakes Trail

bodyText:
Season: Summer

Paradise is open year-round, but this orientation guide is designed for the summer season when trails are snow-free. In spring and fall, there may be patches of snow covering sections of trail. Please stay on trails, even if it means crossing snow, to avoid trampling delicate meadow plants. Pets are not allowed on trails.  

This location is the junction of East Skyline Trail and Mazama Ridge Trail. 

  • East Skyline Trail is oriented roughly east-west at this intersection, with the downhill trail to west when facing Mount Rainier (northwest) and the uphill trail to the east. 
  • Mazama Ridge / Lakes Trail goes to the south, connecting to the High Lakes trail and Reflection Lakes. 

How Far Is It?  

  • Connecting to Paradise Glacier Trail: 0.44 miles, average walking time 17 minutes. 
  • Paradise (Jackson Visitor Center and Upper Parking Lot): 1.4 miles, average walking time 54 minutes, following Skyline Trail downhill to the west and then to the southwest. 
  • Connecting to Reflection Lakes via Mazama Ridge along the Lakes Trail is approximately 2.3 miles with an average walking time of 1 hour, 29 minutes. 

For additional information, download the Paradise Area Trails Map.
audioDescription: This T-shaped trail junction is surrounded by open meadow and conifer trees. The glaciated summit of Mount Rainier is visible on clear days to the north and the jagged peaks of the Tatoosh Range are visible to the south.

title: Paradise Trails Orientation: East Skyline & Paradise Glacier Trail Junction
listingDescription: This location is the junction of the East Skyline Trail and Mazama Ridge Trail.

images.altText: T-shaped trail intersection surrounded by open meadow and glaciated summit of Mount Rainier to the n
images.title: East Skyline & Paradise Glacier Trail
images.caption: Looking north on the East Skyline Trail at the junction with the Paradise Glacier Trail

bodyText:
Season: Summer

Paradise is open year-round, but this orientation guide is designed for the summer season when trails are snow-free. In spring and fall, there may be patches of snow covering sections of trail. Please stay on trails, even if it means crossing snow, to avoid trampling delicate meadow plants. Pets are not allowed on trails.

This location is the junction of East Skyline Trail and Paradise Glacier Trail. Mount Rainier is visible to the north.

  • East Skyline is oriented roughly north-south at this intersection.
  • Paradise Glacier Trail goes to the northeast. This trail is unmaintained. 

How Far Is It?

  • Paradise Glacier: 1.5 miles, average walking time 1 hour, on the Paradise Glacier Trail.
  • Panorama Point: 1.5 miles north (uphill) via the East Skyline Trail, average walking time 1 hour.
  • Paradise (Jackson Visitor Center and Upper Parking Lot): 1.8 miles, average walking time 1 hour 10 minutes following East Skyline Trail downhill to the southwest.

For additional information, download the Paradise Area Trails Map.
audioDescription: This T-shaped trail junction is surrounded by open meadow. The glaciated summit of Mount Rainier is visible on clear days to the northwest and the jagged peaks of the Tatoosh Range are visible to the south.

title: Paradise Trails Orientation: East Skyline & Paradise Inn Trail Junction
listingDescription: This location is the junction of East Skyline Trail and the Paradise Inn Trail.

images.altText: A large trail sign stands next to a paved trail with Mount Rainier visible between the trees.
images.title: Skyline-Paradise Inn Trail Junction
images.caption: A short trail from the Paradise Inn connects to the East Skyline Trail.

bodyText:
Season: Summer
Paradise is open year-round, but this orientation guide is designed for the summer season when trails are snow-free. In spring and fall, there may be patches of snow covering sections of trail. Please stay on trails, even if it means crossing snow, to avoid trampling delicate meadow plants. Pets are not allowed on trails.

At this trail intersection, a short trail connects the Paradise Inn and upper parking lot to the East Skyline Trail. A large trail orientation sign with a map is directly across from the Paradise Inn Trail towards the north, with Mount Rainier barely visible between the trees behind the sign.

  • East Skyline Trail is relatively flat at this location, with an easy climb to the northeast (to the right if looking at the trail sign) and a gentle downhill to the southwest (to the left if looking at the trail sign).
  • Paradise Inn Trail goes due south to the Paradise Inn.  

How Far Is It?

  • Paradise Inn: 0.03 miles, average walking time 2 minutes, by following Paradise Inn Trail downhill to the south. The Paradise Inn has a restaurant, café, gift shop, and a comfortable lobby for those looking to take a break. The Paradise Inn is located on the eastern edge of the upper parking lot.
  • Jackson Visitor Center and Upper Parking Lot: 0.15 miles, average walking time 6 minutes, by following East Skyline Trail to the southwest. Restrooms, water, and gift shop are located in the visitor center.
  • Myrtle Falls: 0.37 mile, average walking time 14 minutes, by following East Skyline Trail to the northeast.

For additional information, download the Paradise Area Trails Map.
audioDescription: The East Skyline Trail is a wide paved trail that gently cuts across the meadow slopes in this location. The meadows are broken by numerous patches of fir trees, with Mount Rainier’s snowy peak just visible between the trees to the north. A large trail sign with two panels supported vertically between tall posts is on the north side of the Skyline Trail across from the junction of a short trail that drops down towards the Paradise Inn, with a set of steep wood steps just before the parking lot in front of the inn. The edges of the paved trails can be abrupt and bordered by low ropes strung between rebar posts to help remind people to stay on the trail.

title: Paradise Trails Orientation: East Skyline & Upper Golden Gate Trail Junction
listingDescription: This location is the junction of East Skyline Trail and Upper Golden Gate Trail.

images.altText: T-shaped intersection surrounded by rocks, patches of open meadow, and conifer trees with glaciated
images.title: East Skyline & Upper Golden Gate Trail
images.caption: Looking north towards Mount Rainier at the intersection of East Skyline & Upper Golden Gate Trail

bodyText:
Season: Summer 

Paradise is open year-round, but this orientation guide is designed for the summer season when trails are snow-free. In spring and fall, there may be patches of snow covering sections of trail. Please stay on trails, even if it means crossing snow, to avoid trampling delicate meadow plants. Pets are not allowed on trails.  

This location is the junction of East Skyline Trail & Upper Golden Gate Trail. The summit of Mount Rainier is located to the north of this junction. 

  • East Skyline Trail is oriented north-south at this intersection, with the uphill trail to the north when facing Mount Rainier, and the downhill trail heading south. 
  • Golden Gate Trail goes downhill to the southwest, connecting to Myrtle Falls and Paradise. This trail is a popular alternative for those looking to cut some distance off the full Skyline loop. 

How Far Is It? 

  • Panorama Point via Skyline Trail: 0.9 miles, average walking time 35 minutes heading north up the Skyline Trail. 
  • Paradise via Golden Gate Trail: 1.5 miles, average walking time 58 minutes. 
  • Paradise via Skyline Trail 2.5 miles, average walking time 1 hour 37 minutes, heading south down the Skyline Trail.

For additional information, download the Paradise Area Trails Map.
audioDescription: This T-shaped trail junction is surrounded by rocks, open patches of meadows, and conifer trees. The glaciated summit of Mount Rainier is visible on clear days to the north.

title: Paradise Trails Orientation: East Skyline & Waterfall Trail Junction
listingDescription: This location is the junction of East Skyline Trail and the Waterfall Trail.

images.altText: A paved trail joins another trail that curves around the edge of a hillside towards a snowy ridge.
images.title: Waterfall-East Skyline Trail Junction
images.caption: The Waterfall Trail (left) joins the East Skyline Trail (right) which climbs towards Mount Rainier.

bodyText:
Season: Summer
Paradise is open year-round, but this orientation guide is designed for the summer season when trails are snow-free. In spring and fall, there may be patches of snow covering sections of trail. Please stay on trails, even if it means crossing snow, to avoid trampling delicate meadow plants. Pets are not allowed on trails.

This location is the junction of East Skyline Trail and the Waterfall Trail. The East Skyline Trail has excellent views of Mount Rainier as it climbs north towards Myrtle Falls (if the weather cooperates).

  • East Skyline Trail goes uphill to the north and downhill to the south before angling southwest.
  • Waterfall Trail heads to the west.

How Far Is It?

  • Myrtle Falls: 0.25 miles, average walking time 10 minutes, by following the east Skyline Trail uphill to the north. (Note that the Waterfall Trail does not lead to Myrtle Falls from this intersection.)
  • Paradise Inn: 0.15 miles, average walking time 6 minutes, by following East Skyline Trail downhill to the south. The Paradise Inn will be visible on the left. It has a restaurant, café, gift shop, and a comfortable lobby for those looking to take a break.
  • Jackson Visitor Center and Upper Parking Lot: 0.21 miles, average walking time 8 minutes, by following East Skyline Trail downhill to the south. Restrooms, water, and gift shop are located in the visitor center.
  • Connecting to west side of the Skyline Trail: 0.19 miles, average walking time 8 minutes, west on the Waterfall Trail. The Skyline Trail is a loop trail. Continue east past Myrtle Falls to continue on the Skyline Trail or head west to complete the loop clockwise. The full loop trail is 5.5 miles.

For additional information, download the Paradise Area Trails Map.
audioDescription: The Waterfall Trails terminates at the East Skyline Trail in this location with the East Skyline Trail creating a three-way junction. As it climbs to the north, the East Skyline Trail skirts the edge of the Paradise Valley, a small valley dotted with fir trees and patches of subalpine meadow, and has excellent views of Mount Rainier. The trails are paved, bordered by shrubs, meadow plants and patches of fir trees. The edges of the paved paths can be abrupt and in summer are marked by rope strung between low rebar posts.

title: Paradise Trails Orientation: Paradise Picnic Area Trailhead
listingDescription: This location is the trailhead of Paradise Picnic Area Connector Trail.

images.altText: A trail starts from a break in a low rock wall bordering a parking area.
images.title: Paradise Picnic Area Trailhead
images.caption: A trail connecting to the Paradise Picnic Area starts from the lower parking lot.

bodyText:
Season: Summer
Paradise is open year-round, but this orientation guide is designed for the summer season when trails are snow-free. In spring and fall, there may be patches of snow covering sections of trail. Please stay on trails, even if it means crossing snow, to avoid trampling delicate meadow plants. Pets are not allowed on trails.

The Paradise Picnic Area Trailhead is located in the lower parking lot at Paradise. The lower lot has a single loop, with the trailhead located at the downhill side of the loop. From this trailhead, there are excellent views of the Tatoosh Range to the southeast and the summit of Mount Rainier to the north.

  • Paradise Picnic Area Connector Trail is on the south side of the parking lot where there is a break in a low rock wall. The trail immediately turns west to go along the wall before turning south to go downhill to the picnic area.

How Far Is It?

  • Paradise Picnic Area: 0.1 miles, average walking time 4 minutes, by following the connector trail downhill. Restrooms and picnic tables are available in the picnic area.
  • Connecting to Nisqually Vista Trail: 0.1 miles, average walking time 4 minutes, by taking the crosswalk to the northeast through the lower parking lot. At the top of the lower parking lot, turn left (west) and follow the sidewalk to the Nisqually Vista Trailhead at the end of the parking lot.
  • Connecting to Alta Vista Trail: 0.05 miles (300 feet), average walking time 2 minutes, by taking the crosswalk to the northeast through the lower parking lot. Keep going straight to connect to the Alta Vista Trailhead.
  • Jackson Visitor Center and Upper Parking Lot: 0.3 miles, average walking time 12 minutes, by taking the crosswalk to the northeast through the lower parking lot. Keep following the sidewalk to the right along the road uphill to the visitor center. Restrooms, water, and gift shop are located in the visitor center. You can also follow the Alta Vista Trail north to the Avalanche Lily Trail to connect to the visitor center, 0.29 miles, average walking time 11 minutes.

For additional information, download the Paradise Area Trails Map.
audioDescription: The Paradise Picnic Area Trailhead is located in the lower parking lot at Paradise. The lower lot has a single loop, with the trailhead located at the downhill side of the loop near where the loop connects to the main road. The parking area has a sidewalk on the outside of the loop bordered by a low rock wall. The trailhead is located at a cut in the wall. A dirt social trail bears to the southeast (left) from the trailhead to a short rise with a viewpoint of the Tatoosh Range, but the main trail immediately turns to the west (right) once through the wall. The trail follows the wall for a short distance before turning south and heading downhill before crossing the main road and reaching the Paradise Picnic Area. Looking north away from the trailhead there is a crosswalk across the parking loop road, with a set of stone steps leading to the top half of the loop. The middle of the loop is planted with shrubs and meadow plants. On clear days, there is an excellent view of Mount Rainier’s glaciated summit to the north.

title: Paradise Trails Orientation: Pebble Creek & Pebble Creek Spur Trail Junction
listingDescription: This location is the junction of Pebble Creek Trail and Pebble Creek Spur Trail.

images.altText: V-shaped intersection surrounded by rocks with glaciated mountain to the north
images.title: Pebble Creek & Pebble Creek Spur Trail
images.caption: Looking north towards Mount Rainier at the intersection of Pebble Creek Trail and Pebble Creek Spur

bodyText:
Season: Summer 

Paradise is open year-round, but this orientation guide is designed for the summer season when trails are snow-free. In spring and fall, there may be patches of snow covering sections of trail. Please stay on trails, even if it means crossing snow, to avoid trampling delicate meadow plants. Pets are not allowed on trails.  

This location is the junction of Skyline Trail and Lower Pebble Creek Trail.

  • Pebble Creek Trail goes to the northeast, connecting to the Muir Snowfield, and downhill to the southwest to connect to Skyline Trail.
  • Pebble Creek Spur goes to the south to connect to the East Skyline Trail and Panorama Point.

How Far Is It?

  • Connecting to Golden Gate Trail via East Skyline Trail: 1.3 miles, average walking time 50 minutes; by following the Pebble Creek Spur Trail down (south) to the East Skyline Trail and taking it to the east. Golden Gate Trail can be used to cut off distance from the east side of the Skyline loop.
  • Connecting to Lakes Trail via East Skyline Trail: 2.3 miles to the junction of East Skyline Trail and Mazama Ridge / Lakes Trail, average walking time 1 hour 29 minutes
  • Paradise via East Skyline Trail: 2.7 miles, average walking time 1 hour 44 minutes, by following the Pebble Creek Spur Trail down (south) to the East Skyline Trail and taking it to the east.
  • Paradise via Skyline Trail: 1.9 miles, average walking 1 hour 14 minutes, by following the Pebble Creek Trail southwest to the Skyline Trail.
  • Panorama Point: 0.5 miles going south on East Skyline, average walking time 19 minutes.

For additional information, download the Paradise Area Trails Map.
audioDescription: This V-shaped trail junction is surrounded by rocks. The glaciated summit of Mount Rainier is visible on clear days to the north.

title: Paradise Trails Orientation: Pebble Creek Spur & Skyline Trail Junction
listingDescription: This location is the junction of Pebble Creek Spur Trail and Skyline Trail.

images.altText: V-shaped intersection with glaciated mountain to the north
images.title: Pebble Creek Spur & Skyline Trail
images.caption: Looking north towards Mount Rainier at the intersection of Pebble Creek Spur Trail and Skyline Trail

bodyText:
Season: Summer 

Paradise is open year-round, but this orientation guide is designed for the summer season when trails are snow-free. In spring and fall, there may be patches of snow covering sections of trail. Please stay on trails, even if it means crossing snow, to avoid trampling delicate meadow plants. Pets are not allowed on trails.  

This location is the junction of Pebble Creek Spur Trail and Skyline Trail.

  • Pebble Creek Spur goes to the northeast, connecting to the Pebble Creek Trail which goes to the Muir Snowfield.
  • Skyline Trail goes downhill to the south to connect to Panorama Point and East Skyline continues downhill to the east to connect to Golden Gate Trail and Mazama Ridge Trail.

How Far Is It?

  • Pebble Creek: 0.3 miles via Pebble Creek Spur (0.03 miles) and Pebble Creek Trail. The Pebble Creek Trail ends at a sign marking the end of the maintained trail and the start of the route to the Muir Snowfield. The Muir Snowfield is s a permanent snowfield and requires navigation and winter travel skills. Crampons or microspikes required. Late in the season the snowfield can get icy with open crevasses. Know before you go and check conditions before continuing to Camp Muir. 
  • Connecting to Golden Gate Trail via East Skyline Trail: 1.3 miles, average walking time 50 minutes. Golden Gate Trail can be used to cut off distance from the east side of the Skyline loop. 
  • Connecting to Lakes Trail via East Skyline Trail: 2.3 miles to the junction of East Skyline Trail and Mazama Ridge / Lakes Trail, average walking time 1 hour 29 minutes 
  • Paradise via East Skyline Trail: 2.7 miles, average walking time 1 hour 44 minutes, by going to the east. 
  • Paradise via Skyline Trail: 1.9 miles, average walking 1 hour 14 minutes to the south to Panorama Point and then to the west along the Skyline Trail. 
  • Panorama Point: 0.5 miles going south on Skyline, average walking time 19 minutes. 

For additional information, download the Paradise Area Trails Map.
audioDescription: This V-shaped trail junction is surrounded open meadow and rocks. The glaciated summit of Mount Rainier is visible on clear days to the north.

title: Paradise Trails Orientation: Skyline & Alta Vista Trail Junction
listingDescription: This location is the lower junction of Skyline Trail and Alta Vista Trail.

images.altText: Intersection of two paved trails on a hillside framing a stand of subalpine fir trees.
images.title: Skyline-Alta Vista Junction
images.caption: Skyline Trail leads to the left while Alta Vista Trail climbs to the right.

bodyText:
Season: Summer
Paradise is open year-round, but this orientation guide is designed for the summer season when trails are snow-free. In spring and fall, there may be patches of snow covering sections of trail. Please stay on trails, even if it means crossing snow, to avoid trampling delicate meadow plants. Pets are not allowed on trails.

This location is the lower junction of Skyline Trail and Alta Vista Trail, with north located midway between the two uphill branches of the trails.

  • Skyline Trail goes downhill to the east with the uphill trail angling to the northwest.
  • Alta Vista Trail goes to the south downhill and angles northeast if traveling uphill.

How Far Is It?

  • Lower Parking Lot: 0.38 miles, average walking time 15 minutes, south on Alta Vista Trail (downhill). The Nisqually Vista Trailhead is located on the western end of the lower parking lot. There are no restrooms in the lower parking lot, but restrooms are available in the Paradise Picnic Area, downhill from the lower parking lot.
  • Jackson Visitor Center and Upper Parking Lot: 0.19 miles, average walking time 8 minutes, by following the Skyline Trail downhill to the upper parking lot.
  • Connecting to Deadhorse Creek Trail: 0.28 miles, average walking time 11 minutes, northwest on Skyline Trail (uphill) to a wye intersection. Skyline Trail is to the right while a short spur trail connects to Deadhorse Creek Trail on the left. Deadhorse Creek trail continues to parallel Skyline Trail and reconnects to the Skyline Trail higher up in the meadows. Or, follow Deadhorse Creek Trail downhill to connect to the Nisqually Vista Trail.
  • Myrtle Falls: 0.49 miles, average walking time 19 minutes, by following the Skyline Trail east (downhill) then take the Waterfall Trail. The Waterfall Trail terminates at the junction with the eastern branch of the Skyline Trail. Follow the Skyline Trail north to Myrtle Falls.
  • Connecting to Upper Alta Vista Trail/Dancefloor: Follow either the Skyline or the Alta Vista Trails uphill to where the two trails intersect again, in a rare flat area nicknamed the “Dancefloor”. If using the Skyline Trail: 0.44 miles, average walking time 17 minutes. If using the Alta Vista Trail, hike the steep trail to a junction where the Alta Vista Trail splits, the main trail climbing to the left, 0.48 miles, average walking time 19 minutes, or take the East Alta Vista trail to the right, 0.40 miles, average walking time 16 minutes. Both branches of the Alta Vista Trail lead to the Dancefloor and have excellent views of the surrounding area.

For additional information, download the Paradise Area Trails Map.
audioDescription: This intersection of two trails forms an X-shaped junction with the uphill branches of the trails framing tall confirm trees while patches of meadows and trees border the downhill trails. The trails are paved but steep and trail edges can be abrupt or bordered with rocks. On the west side of the Skyline Trail, large rocks form shallow steps along the trail’s border with a log at the edge of the trail serving as a bench.

title: Paradise Trails Orientation: Skyline & Lower Glacier Vista Trail Junction
listingDescription: This location is the junction of Skyline Trail and Lower Glacier Vista Trail.

images.altText: V-shaped trail junction is surrounded by open meadow and rocks with glaciated summit to the north
images.title: Skyline & Lower Glacier Vista Trail
images.caption: Intersection of Skyline Trail and Lower Glacier Vista Trail looking north towards Mount Rainier

bodyText:
Season: Summer 

Paradise is open year-round, but this orientation guide is designed for the summer season when trails are snow-free. In spring and fall, there may be patches of snow covering sections of trail. Please stay on trails, even if it means crossing snow, to avoid trampling delicate meadow plants. Pets are not allowed on trails.  

This location is the junction of Skyline Trail and Lower Glacier Vista Trail. 

  • Skyline Trail is oriented north-south at this intersection, going uphill to the north to Panorama Point and downhill to the south to Paradise.
  • Glacier Vista Trail goes to the northwest to a viewpoint of the Nisqually Glacier before rejoining the Skyline Trail.  

How Far Is It?

  • Panorama Point: 0.8 miles, average walking time 31 minutes, north on the Skyline Trail.
  • Glacier Vista Viewpoint: 0.2 miles, average walking time 8 minutes. This is a short detour that runs parallel to the Skyline Trail.
  • Paradise via Skyline Trail: 1.1 miles, average walking time 43 minutes.

For additional information, download the Paradise Area Trails Map.
audioDescription: This V-shaped trail junction is surrounded by open meadow and rocks. The glaciated summit of Mount Rainier is visible on clear days to the north. The Glacier Vista trail leads to a view of the Nisqually Glacier and a waterfall.

title: Paradise Trails Orientation: Skyline & Lower Pebble Creek Trail Junction
listingDescription: This location is the junction of Skyline Trail and Lower Pebble Creek Trail.

images.altText: Glaciated mountain and rocky stairs to the north at a V-shaped trail junction surrounded by meadow
images.title: Skyline & Lower Pebble Creek Trail
images.caption: Looking north towards Mount Rainier at the junction of Skyline and Lower Pebble Creek Trail.

bodyText:
Season: Summer 

Paradise is open year-round, but this orientation guide is designed for the summer season when trails are snow-free. In spring and fall, there may be patches of snow covering sections of trail. Please stay on trails, even if it means crossing snow, to avoid trampling delicate meadow plants. Pets are not allowed on trails.  

This location is the junction of Skyline Trail and Lower Pebble Creek Trail.

  • Skyline Trail is oriented roughly east-west at this intersection, with the uphill trail to the southeast when facing Mount Rainier (north) and the downhill trail heading northwest.
  • Pebble Creek Trail goes to the north, connecting to the Muir Snowfield.  

How Far Is It?

  • Panorama Point via Skyline Trail: 0.3 miles, average walking time 12 minutes, east on the Skyline Trail.
  • Paradise via Skyline Trail: 1.6 miles, average walking time 1 hour 2 minutes, west (downhill) on the Skyline Trail.
  • Paradise via East Skyline Trail: 3.6 miles, average walking time 2 hours, 19 minutes, east on the Skyline Trail past Panorama Point where the trail becomes the East Skyline Trail.
  • Pebble Creek: 0.8 miles, average walking time 31 minutes. The Pebble Creek Trail ends at the sign about crevasses on the Muir Snowfield.
  • Camp Muir via Pebble Creek Trail: 2.7 miles; Camp Muir sits at over 10,000 feet in elevation (more than 3,000 feet of climbing from this junction) and requires hiking up the Muir Snowfield, which is a permanent snowfield and requires navigation and winter travel skills. Crampons or microspikes required. Late in the season the snowfield can get icy with open crevasses. Know before you go and check conditions before continuing to Camp Muir.

For additional information, download the Paradise Area Trails Map.
audioDescription: This V-shaped trail junction is surrounded by open patches of meadow and is located on a steep slope. The glaciated summit of Mount Rainier is visible on clear days to the north. The trail up to Pebble Creek to the north is made up of rocky stairs. The trail to continue to Panorama Point to the southeast has expansive views to the southwest of the meadows below.

title: Paradise Trails Orientation: Skyline & Upper Deadhorse Creek Trail Junction
listingDescription: This location is the junction of Skyline Trail and Upper Deadhorse Creek Trail.

images.altText: T-shaped intersection surrounded by patches of open meadow with glaciated summit of Mount Rainier to
images.title: Skyline & Upper Deadhorse Creek Trail
images.caption: Looking north towards Mount Rainier at the intersection of Skyline and Upper Deadhorse Creek Trail

bodyText:
Season: Summer

Paradise is open year-round, but this orientation guide is designed for the summer season when trails are snow-free. In spring and fall, there may be patches of snow covering sections of trail. Please stay on trails, even if it means crossing snow, to avoid trampling delicate meadow plants. Pets are not allowed on trails.

This location is the junction of Skyline Trail and Upper Deadhorse Creek Trail.

  • Skyline Trail is oriented north to south, with the uphill trail heading north in the direction of Mount Rainier.
  • Deadhorse Creek goes downhill to the southwest, connecting to the Jackson Visitor Center and the upper Paradise parking lot.

How Far Is It?

  • Paradise via Deadhorse Creek Trail: 1 mile, average walking time 39 minutes.
  • Paradise via Skyline Trail: 1 mile, average walking time 39 minutes.
  • Panorama Point via Skyline Trail: 0.9 miles, average walking time 34 minutes.

For additional information, download the Paradise Area Trails Map.
audioDescription: This T-shaped intersection is surrounded by patches of open meadow and rocks. The glaciated summit of Mount Rainier is visible on clear days to the north.

title: Paradise Trails Orientation: Skyline & Upper Glacier Vista Trail Junction
listingDescription: This location is the junction of Skyline Trail and Upper Glacier Vista Trail.

images.altText: V-shaped trail intersection surrounded by open meadow with glaciated summit of Mount Rainier to the
images.title: Skyline & Upper Glacier Vista Trail
images.caption: Intersection of Skyline Trail and Upper Glacier Vista Trail looking north towards Mount Rainier

bodyText:
Season: Summer 

Paradise is open year-round, but this orientation guide is designed for the summer season when trails are snow-free. In spring and fall, there may be patches of snow covering sections of trail. Please stay on trails, even if it means crossing snow, to avoid trampling delicate meadow plants. Pets are not allowed on trails.  

This location is the junction of Skyline Trail and Upper Glacier Vista Trail. This location features an exhibit panel called Tough Place to Bloom.

  • Skyline Trail is oriented north-south at this intersection, going uphill to the north to Panorama Point and downhill to the south to Paradise.
  • Glacier Vista Trail goes to southwest to a viewpoint of the Nisqually Glacier before rejoining the Skyline Trail.  

How Far Is It?

  • Panorama Point: 0.6 miles, average walking time 23 minutes, north (uphill) on the Skyline Trail.
  • Glacier Vista Trail Viewpoint: 0.2 miles, average walking time 8 minutes. This is a short detour that runs parallel to the Skyline Trail.
  • Paradise via Skyline Trail: 1.3 miles, average walking time 50 minutes.

For additional information, download the Paradise Area Trails Map.
audioDescription: This V-shaped trail junction is surrounded by open meadow and rocks. The glaciated summit of Mount Rainier is visible on clear days to the north. The Glacier Vista trail leads to a view of the Nisqually Glacier and a waterfall.

title: Paradise Trails Orientation: Skyline Trail & Deadhorse Creek Connector Trail Junction
listingDescription: This location is the junction of Skyline Trail and Deadhorse Creek connector trail.

images.altText: A paved trail branches off a trail and climbs a hillside towards a glaciated peak.
images.title: Skyline-Deadhorse Connector
images.caption: At this location, keep to the right to stay on the Skyline Trail.

bodyText:
Season: Summer
Paradise is open year-round, but this orientation guide is designed for the summer season when trails are snow-free. In spring and fall, there may be patches of snow covering sections of trail. Please stay on trails, even if it means crossing snow, to avoid trampling delicate meadow plants. Pets are not allowed on trails.

This location is the junction of Skyline Trail and a connector trail to the Deadhorse Creek Trail. North is located between the two uphill trails, with the summit of Mount Rainier to the northwest.

  • Skyline Trail goes to the northeast uphill and to the south downhill.
  • The connector trail goes uphill to the northwest to connect to the Deadhorse Creek Trail.  

How Far Is It?

  • Connecting to Deadhorse Creek Trail: 0.09 miles, average walking time 4 minutes, northwest on the connector trail (uphill).
  • Jackson Visitor Center and Upper Parking Lot: 0.47 miles, average walking time 19 minutes, by following the connector trail downhill to the Skyline Trail to descend to the upper parking lot. Restrooms, information, food, and gifts available at the visitor center.
  • Connecting to Alta Vista Trail: 0.18 miles, average walking time 7 minutes, northeast uphill on the Skyline Trail.

For additional information, download the Paradise Area Trails Map.
audioDescription: At this three-way intersection the paved Skyline Trail travels up and down the slopes of Mount Rainier while the short, paved connector trail diagonally cuts uphill across a slope to reach the Deadhorse Creek Trail. Right at the start of the connector trail, the trail crosses over a small rocky creek, with goes through a culvert under the trail. The edges of the paved trails may be abrupt or bordered by rocks. Both trails are bordered by subalpine meadows dotted with boulders with excellent views of the glaciated summit of Mount Rainier. To the southwest, the Tatoosh Range, a ridge of rocky peaks, is visible through a gap between trees.

title: Paradise Trails Orientation: Skyline-Alta Vista-Dancefloor Trail Junction
listingDescription: This location is the upper junction of Skyline and Alta Vista Trails at a rare flat area called the “Dancefloor”.

images.altText: A large, paved area with several trails branching from it with views of Mount Rainier.
images.title: Skyline Trail-Dancefloor
images.caption: The "Dancefloor" is a rare flat rest stop along the Skyline Trail.

bodyText:
Season: Summer
Paradise is open year-round, but this orientation guide is designed for the summer season when trails are snow-free. In spring and fall, there may be patches of snow covering sections of trail. Please stay on trails, even if it means crossing snow, to avoid trampling delicate meadow plants. Pets are not allowed on trails.

This location is the upper junction of Skyline Trail and Alta Vista Trail. The large flat rest area at this intersection is known as the “Dancefloor”. The summit of Mount Rainier is to the northwest.

  • Skyline Trail goes uphill to the north with the downhill trail to the southwest.
  • Alta Vista Trail goes to the south downhill, then branches into two trails about 100 feet from the Dancefloor. The main Alta Vista Trail branch climbs to the top of Alta Vista peak (elevation 5,940 feet) while the east trail branch curves around the east side of the slope as it travels downhill. Both branches reconnect on the other side of Alta Vista before rejoining the Skyline Trail at a lower elevation.

How Far Is It?

  • Alta Vista Peak: 0.1 miles, average walking time 4 minutes, south on the Alta Vista Trail, then take the main branch (on the right) to climb up to the peak. The viewpoint at the peak has excellent views of the surrounding Paradise area, Mount Rainier to the northwest, and the Tatoosh Range and Mount Adams to the south.
  • Connecting to Panorama Point: 0.79 miles, average walking time 30 minutes, north on the Skyline Trail (uphill). Panorama Point is a popular viewpoint along the upper portion of the trail. A restroom is available near the point.
  • Jackson Visitor Center and Upper Parking Lot: 0.63 miles, average walking time 25 minutes, by following the Skyline Trail downhill to the upper parking lot. Or, take the East Alta Vista Trail downhill, connecting to the Skyline Trail, 0.61 miles, average walking time 23 minutes. Restrooms, information, food, and gifts available at the visitor center.

For additional information, download the Paradise Area Trails Map.
audioDescription: The “Dancefloor” is a large, flat paved area surrounded by subalpine meadows and excellent views of Mount Rainier. The Dancefloor forms a rough rectangle. If oriented to the north, with the peak of Mount Rainier slightly to the left in the northwest, the uphill branch of the Skyline Trail leaves from roughly the middle of the rectangle, climbing up a ridge line. The uphill trail is dirt and gravel, broken by wood steps. The downhill side of the Skyline Trail starts from the lower left corner of the rectangle and is paved. The edges of the paved trail can be abrupt. The Alta Vista Trail starts in the lower right corner of the rectangle (opposite side of the Dancefloor from Mount Rainier). It is a narrower dirt trail. A short distance from the Dancefloor the Alta Vista Trail splits, with one branch steeply climbing up to a nearby rocky peak, while the other branch more gently descends around the side of the peak. Benches made from large logs frame the right side of the Dancefloor.

title: Paradise Trails Orientation: Skyline-Waterfall-Guide House Trail Junction
listingDescription: This location is the junction of Skyline Trail, Waterfall Trail, and Guide House Connector Trail.

images.altText: Two paved trails cross on a hillside surrounded by fall vegetation and conifer trees.
images.title: Skyline-Waterfall-GuideHouse Trails
images.caption: The Waterfall-Skyline Trail crossing, with the peak of Mount Rainier barely visible to the north.

bodyText:
Season: Summer
Paradise is open year-round, but this orientation guide is designed for the summer season when trails are snow-free. In spring and fall, there may be patches of snow covering sections of trail. Please stay on trails, even if it means crossing snow, to avoid trampling delicate meadow plants. Pets are not allowed on trails.

This location is the junction of Skyline Trail, Waterfall Trail, and Guide House Connector Trail. This can be a confusing intersection. The Guide House Connector trail intersects with the Skyline Trail a short distance downhill from the intersection of the Waterfall Trail, resulting in a junction with trails leading in five directions.

  • Skyline Trail goes downhill to the south while the uphill trail angles steeply to the west.
  • Waterfall Trail is less steep and goes uphill to the southwest, while the downhill trail goes to the east.
  • Guide House Connector Trail branches off the downhill portion of the Skyline Trail to the southeast.

How Far Is It?

  • Lower Parking Lot: 0.39 miles, average walking time 15 minutes, southwest on Waterfall Trail to connect to the Alta Vista Trail, then follow the Alta Vista Trail downhill. The Nisqually Vista Trailhead is located on the western end of the lower parking lot. There are no restrooms in the lower parking lot, but restrooms are available in the Paradise Picnic Area, downhill from the lower parking lot.
  • Jackson Visitor Center and Upper Parking Lot: 0.13 miles, average walking time 5 minutes, by following the Skyline Trail downhill to the upper parking lot. Restrooms, water, and gift shop are located in the visitor center.
  • Connecting to Deadhorse Creek Trail: 0.23 miles, average walking time 9 minutes, southwest on Waterfall Trail. Deadhorse Creek trail parallels Skyline Trail and reconnects to the Skyline Trail higher up in the meadows. Or, follow Deadhorse Creek Trail downhill to connect to the Nisqually Vista Trail.
  • Myrtle Falls: 0.44 miles, average walking time 17 minutes, by following Waterfall Trail east. The Waterfall Trail terminates at the junction with the eastern branch of the Skyline Trail. Follow the Skyline Trail north (left) to Myrtle Falls.
  • Guide House & Climbing Information Center: 0.11 miles, average walking time 4 minutes, by following the Guide House Connector Trail downhill. The entrance to the Climbing Information Center is on the east side of the Guide House (side facing the Paradise Inn).
  • Paradise Inn: 0.34 miles, average walking time 13 minutes, by following Waterfall Trail east then turning southwest (right) on the eastern Skyline Trail. Or, follow the Guide House Connector Trail, 0.14 miles/6 minutes, southeast to the upper parking lot. The Paradise Inn is on the east side of the parking lot and has a restaurant, café, gift shop, and a comfortable lobby for those looking to take a break.

For additional information, download the Paradise Area Trails Map.
audioDescription: Two trails, the Skyline and Waterfall Trails, forms a rough X-shaped junction, with a third trail, the Guide House Connector Trail, branching off the downhill leg of the Skyline Trail just below the X-shape, creating an intersection of five paths. The trails are paved, bordered by shrubs, meadow plants and patches of fir trees. The edges of the paved paths can be abrupt and in summer are marked by rope strung between low rebar posts.

title: Paradise Trails Orientation: Waterfall & Alta Vista Trail Junction
listingDescription: This location is the junction of Waterfall Trail and Alta Vista Trail. A memorial plaque for the 10th Memorial Division is located nearby.

images.altText: A bronze memorial plaque set into a small boulder next to a trail in front of Mount Rainier.
images.title: 10th Mountain Memorial at Paradise
images.caption: The 10th Mountain Division Memorial near the intersection of the Waterfall & Alta Vista Trails.

bodyText:
Season: Summer
Paradise is open year-round, but this orientation guide is designed for the summer season when trails are snow-free. In spring and fall, there may be patches of snow covering sections of trail. Please stay on trails, even if it means crossing snow, to avoid trampling delicate meadow plants. Pets are not allowed on trails.

This location is the junction of Waterfall Trail and Alta Vista Trail, with north located midway between the two uphill branches of the trails looking roughly towards Mount Rainier. Also on the north side of the junction is a bench next to a small boulder with a bronze plaque inset into it memorializing the 10th Mountain Division, which trained on Mount Rainier in 1941-42 before serving in World War II.

  • Waterfall Trail is oriented roughly east-west at this intersection, with the downhill trail to the east and the uphill hill trail angling to the northwest.

  • Alta Vista Trail goes to the south downhill and angles northeast if traveling uphill.

How Far Is It?

  • Lower Parking Lot: 0.34 miles, average walking time 13 minutes, south on Alta Vista Trail (downhill). The Nisqually Vista Trailhead is located on the western end of the lower parking lot. There are no restrooms in the lower parking lot, but restrooms are available in the Paradise Picnic Area, downhill from the parking lot.
  • Connecting to Skyline Trail: Both Alta Vista and Waterfall Trails cross the Skyline Trail nearby: 0.04 miles (211 ft), average walking time 1.5 minutes, northeast on Alta Vista Trail (uphill) or 0.5 miles (260 ft), average walking time 2 minutes, east on Waterfall Trail (downhill).
  • Jackson Visitor Center and Upper Parking Lot: 0.19 miles, average walking time 7 minutes, by following the Waterfall Trail east to the Skyline Trail then taking the Skyline Trail downhill to the upper parking lot. An alternative and less direct route is to go south on Alta Vista Trail (downhill) then take Avalanche Lily Trail east to connect to the upper parking lot, 0.32 miles, average walking time 12 minutes. Restrooms, information, food, and gifts available at the visitor center.
  • Connecting to Deadhorse Creek Trail: 0.18 miles, average walking time 7 minutes, northwest on Waterfall Trail (uphill). Deadhorse Creek Trail parallels and connects to the Skyline Trail higher up in the meadows or follow Deadhorse Creek Trail downhill to connect to the Nisqually Vista Trail.
  • Myrtle Falls: 0.49 miles, average walking time 19 minutes, east on Waterfall Trail. Stay on the Waterfall Trail past the first intersection with the Skyline Trail until the Waterfall Trail terminates at the junction with the eastern branch of the Skyline Trail. Follow the Skyline Trail north to Myrtle Falls.

For additional information, download the Paradise Area Trails Map.
audioDescription: This intersection of two trails forms an X-shaped junction with the glaciated summit of Mount Rainier rising to the north above a meadow slope interspersed with tall conifer trees. The trails are paved but steep and trail edges can be abrupt or bordered with rocks. On the north side of the Waterfall Trail, just to the northwest of the intersection, is a small gravel area with two log benches. One bench parallels the trail in the middle of the gravel area while another bench is perpendicular trail at the edge of the area. Bench locations may change. At the edge of the gravel area surrounded by meadow plants is a boulder about two feet high with a circular bronze plaque inset into the boulder’s surface.

title: Paradise-Stevens Glacier
listingDescription: Nearly a century ago, the ice caves of the Paradise-Stevens Glacier were one of the main attractions of the park. Today, the glacier has rapidly retreated, leaving a barren rocky valley.

images.altText: The Paradise-Stevens Glacier has retreated leaving behind a barren, rocky valley.
images.title: Paradise-Stevens Glacier
images.caption: Paradise-Stevens Glacier

bodyText:
Nearly a century ago, one of the main attractions in the park was the Paradise-Stevens Glacier area. At that time, Paradise-Stevens Glacier was riddled with ice caves and crevasses and was within easy walking distance of major roads. An 1896 map of the glacier places its terminus within 0.6 mile (1 km) of Sluiskin Falls. However, by the 1970s the glacier area had decreased to less than 50% of its 1896 area and separated into two small segments of stagnant ice (glacier ice no longer in motion). The rapid melting of the ice left behind a large area strewn with boulders and rubble carried by the glacier and its meltwater streams, providing visitors with an uncommon opportunity to observe the rock features at the bed of a glacier.

In 2023, the Stevens Glacier was officially removed from the Park’s inventory, due to its lack of features indicating flow, and therefore is no longer a glacier but instead a perennial snowfield.

Viewing Paradise-Stevens Glacier: From Paradise, take the Skyline Trail counter-clockwise for 1.8 miles to the junction with the Paradise Glacier Trail. This trail offers views of the Paradise-Stevens Glacier and continues for 1 mile until it ends at an “End of Maintained Trail” sign.

Paradise Glacier Statistics as of 2021 (Beason et al., 2023):

  • A0.224 ± 0.014 square miles (0.581 ± 0.035 km2) (Rank: 21 of glaciers on Mount Rainier)
  • Highest Elevation (Head): 8,425 feet (2,568 m)
  • Lowest Elevation (Terminus): 6,850 feet (2,088 m)
  • Elevation Range: 1,575 feet (480 m)
  • Length: 0.41 miles (0.65 km)
  • Average Slope: 24.07°
  • Average Flow Direction (direction the glacier flows towards): East southeast (124°)
  • Glacier Type: C - Cirque Glacier, or Glacier Head Starts Below Summit
audioDescription: The Paradise-Stevens Glacier has retreated leaving behind a barren, rocky valley with glacial meltwater streams running off the cliffs, collecting into Stevens Creek. The glacier is visible high up on the cliff from the Paradise Glacier Trail.

title: Puyallup Glacier
listingDescription: Puyallup Glacier begins high on the mountain in Sunset Amphitheater and ends in a hanging valley.

images.altText: Hanging valley glacier on rock above lake
images.title: Puyallup Glacier from Aurora Lake
images.caption: Puyallup Glacier from Aurora Lake

bodyText:
Located on the west side of Mount Rainier, Puyallup Glacier begins high up on the mountain in Sunset Amphitheater, a large open basin immediately below the summit. Puyallup is the name of an Indian tribe whose traditional lands include the area around the Puyallup River and Commencement Bay and is one of the park’s associated tribes. The word is said to mean '...shadow from the dense shade of the forest...' (Reese, 2009).

Currently the glacier ends in a hanging valley at the head of the North Puyallup River valley. During seasons of above normal snow accumulation in the Amphitheater, a large ice bulge forms and begins moving down the glacier. When it does so, the terminus advances to the edge of the hanging valley. One such wave in 1960 produced numerous crevasses in the upper part of the glacier. By 1962, the ice in the upper glacier was smooth again while the terminus had advanced, covering rocks that had previously been exposed.

Fifteen thousand years ago, Puyallup Glacier was joined to South and North Mowich Glaciers forming a single ice mass. The farthest advance of the Puyallup Glacier in recent history occurred around 1840, when it flowed well over the edge of the hanging valley.

Viewing Puyallup Glacier: One of the most impressive views of the terminus of Puyallup Glacier is from Klapatche Park. Hike/bike Westside Road (road closed to vehicles at Dry Creek) to the St. Andrews Trailhead. Hike the trail 2.5 miles (4 km) to reach Klapatche Park.

Puyallup Glacier Statistics as of 2021 (Beason et al., 2023):

  • Aerial Extent: 1.196 ± 0.065 square miles (3.098 ± 0.169 km2) (Rank: 9 of 29 glaciers on Mount Rainier)
  • Highest Elevation (Head): 9,600 feet (2,926 m)
  • Lowest Elevation (Terminus): 5,506 feet (1,678 m)
  • Elevation Range: 4,093 feet (1,248 m)
  • Length: 2.47 miles (3.98 km)
  • Average Slope: 19.53°
  • Average Flow Direction (direction the glacier flows towards): West (280°)
  • Glacier Type: C - Cirque Glacier, or Glacier Head Starts Below Summit
audioDescription: Located on the west side of Mount Rainier, the Puyallup Glacier begins high up on the mountain at 9,600 feet in Sunset Amphitheater, a large open basin immediately below the summit. Currently the glacier ends in a hanging valley at the head of the North Puyallup River valley. Its terminus is at elevation of 5,506 feet.

title: Ranger Falls
listingDescription: Ranger Falls is a dramatic 3-segmented waterfall in the Carbon River area.

images.altText: 3 -segmented waterfall with height of 172 feet
images.title: Ranger Falls
images.caption: Ranger Falls

bodyText:
Water Source: Ranger Creek

Waterfall Description: This impressive 3-segmented waterfall has several drops with a total height of 172 feet. The tallest drop is 73 feet high.

Viewing Location: This dramatic cascade is visible from a viewpoint along the trail to Green Lake. Hike or bike 3.2 miles up the Carbon River Road to the Green Lake Trail, then continue on foot 1 mile toward Green Lake to the viewpoint. Bikes are not allowed on trails.
audioDescription: Ranger Falls is a 3-segmented waterfall with several drops and a total height of 172 feet. The tallest drop is 73 feet high.

title: Reflection Lakes
listingDescription: Reflection Lakes are a popular destination along Stevens Canyon Road for scenic reflections of Mount Rainier, wildflower viewing, and hiking.

images.altText: A glaciated mountain and forested slopes reflected in a still mountain lake.
images.title: Reflection Lakes
images.caption: Mount Rainier in Reflections Lakes on a calm morning.

bodyText:
Season: Summer Only (June - September)
Reflection Lakes is located along Stevens Canyon Road which is open to vehicles during the summer season, typically from late June-September. NOTE: From May 24 - September 2, 2024, timed entry reservations are required to enter the Paradise Corridor, which includes Reflection Lakes, between 7:00 am and 3:00 pm. 

This popular destination is named for lakes that reflect views of Mount Rainier. During the summer, hikers must stay on trails at all times to protect the delicate subalpine meadows around the lake. Boating and fishing is not permitted in Reflection Lakes. During the winter, snowshoers and hikers can still access the area and winter camp around the snow-covered lake. 

Hiking
Several trails intersect around Reflection Lakes. The Lakes Trail is an approximately three-mile loop trail that starts from either end of the parking lots next to the lakes. Starting from the west side of the lake, the trail climbs up to the ridge above the lake, follows the ridge to Faraway Rock, then descends back to the lake. Faraway Rock overlooks Louise Lake and Stevens Canyon to the east, as well as providing views to the southwest of the Tatoosh Range and Reflection Lakes. The trail is dirt, broken at times by tree roots and rocks. The eastern side of the loop from Faraway Rock to Reflection Lakes is steeper, with rock and log steps. Trails connecting to the Lakes Trail lead to Paradise through the Paradise Valley or along Mazama Ridge to the Skyline Trail.

Pinnacle Peak Trail is a popular 2.5-mile roundtrip trail that starts to the south of Reflection Lakes. The rocky trail climbs 1,050 feet up several switchbacks through subalpine meadows to a saddle between Pinnacle Peak and Plummer Peak in the Tatoosh Range. The trail can have patches of snow lingering well into summer and steep, exposed drop-offs. From the saddle, view Mount Rainier to the north or look south for glimpses of Mount Adams and Mount St. Helens. Pinnacle Peak Trail reaches the edge of the designated Butter Creek Research Natural Area (RNA). This is intended as a pristine natural area for ecological study and is closed to public use except pursuant to a scientific research permit, consistent with the national RNA system. Please stay on the trail and follow Leave No Trace principles.

The Wonderland Trail also connects to Reflection Lakes. To the west, the Wonderland Trail descends towards Narada Falls, while to the east the trail follows Stevens Canyon.
audioDescription: Reflection Lakes are tucked between Mount Rainier to the north and the Tatoosh Range to the south at the northwest end of Stevens Canyon. The lakes are surrounded by forest with patches of subalpine meadow around the shore. The largest of the Reflection Lakes is framed by Stevens Canyon Road, with long stretches of parking and paved sidewalks along the lake side. A secondary, smaller lake is to the east. The sidewalk along the road is bordered by a low rock wall with metal-framed wayside exhibits along the wall at two locations. Stone steps lead down to a dirt trail on either end of the parking and in the center. On the opposite side of the road from the center parking area is the trailhead for the Pinnacle Peak Trail, with a trail information sign in a wood frame to the right of the trailhead.

quickFacts.value: Approximately 1.3 miles east of the Paradise Road wye along Stevens Canyon Road.
quickFacts.name: Location

title: Reflection Lakes Exhibit Panel
listingDescription: Once damaged by overuse, the park has worked to restore these beautiful lakes.

images.altText: A wayside panel attached to a low rock wall overlooks a lake and view of Mount Rainier.
images.title: Reflection Lakes Wayside
images.caption: Reflection Lakes continues to be a popular destination for generations of visitors.

bodyText:
Title: Rescuing Reflection Lakes


Main Text
From the earliest days of tourism, many people have been attracted to this classic view of Mount Rainier. A boat concession which began in 1927 and the stocking of non-native fish had unintended consequences: the lakeshore and surrounding meadows were damaged by increased recreational activity. Eventually the lakes were closed to fishing, boating, and swimming due to their negative impact on the lake ecosystem. Fish stocking was stopped in 1973. 

Now the National Park Service is taking steps to restore the area's beauty by clearly delineating trails and revegetating the spiderweb of informal paths and bare ground. You can help by staying on trails and never short-cutting. 

Secondary Text
If the air and water are still - usually in early morning - the lake perfectly mirrors the mountain. 

Exhibit Panel Description
A single black and white historic photo fills the exhibit panel with the main text stretching across the top third of the photo. The historic photo shows a line of small row boats in a lake with people in historic swimming costumes sitting in the boats. A caption reads: "Historic photo of boaters on Reflection Lake, 1929. Fishing, boating, and swimming are no longer permitted on the lakes." A smaller, color photo in the upper right corner of the panel shows Mount Rainier reflecting in a still lake, with a dead tree trunk lying on the shore of the lake surrounded by grass. The secondary text is above the small photo. A small box in the lower left corner of the panel reads "User Fee Project. Your Fee Dollars at Work. Entrance fees were used to produce this exhibit".

Visit This Exhibit Panel
This exhibit panel is on the east side of the main parking lot at Reflection Lakes. Reflection Lakes is approximately 1.3 miles east of the Paradise Road wye along Stevens Canyon Road, which is open to vehicles during the summer season, typically from June-September.
audioDescription: Reflection Lakes are tucked between Mount Rainier to the north and the Tatoosh Range to the south at the northwest end of Stevens Canyon. The lakes are surrounded by forest with patches of subalpine meadow around the shore. The largest of the Reflection Lakes is framed by Stevens Canyon Road, with long stretches of parking and paved sidewalks along the lake side. A secondary, smaller lake is to the east. The sidewalk along the road is bordered by a low rock wall with a metal-framed exhibit panel along the wall. Stone steps lead down to a dirt trail on either end of the parking and in the center. On the opposite side of the road from the center parking area is the trailhead for the Pinnacle Peak Trail, with a trail information sign in a wood frame to the right of the trailhead. Exhibit Panel Description A single black and white historic photo fills the exhibit panel with the main text stretching across the top third of the photo. The historic photo shows a line of small row boats in a lake with people in historic swimming costumes sitting in the boats. A caption reads: "Historic photo of boaters on Reflection Lake, 1929. Fishing, boating, and swimming are no longer permitted on the lakes." A smaller, color photo in the upper right corner of the panel shows Mount Rainier reflecting in a still lake, with a dead tree trunk lying on the shore of the lake surrounded by grass. The secondary text is above the small photo. A small box in the lower left corner of the panel reads "User Fee Project. Your Fee Dollars at Work. Entrance fees were used to produce this exhibit".
